repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
To increase execution speed of vim.trim for long only whitespace strings it requires to firstly strip whitespace characters with `gsub('^%s+', '')` and only then get match with `match('^.*%S').

Changes to `vim_spec.lua` were made to cover more cases and fix wrong usage of `assert` instead of `eq`.

Benchmarks can be found here https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34122#issuecomment-2902291021

Closes #34097

comment_data.body:
`shared.lua` is special because the test runner uses it with a limited Nvim (`nvim -ll`) which doesn't have some modules like `vim.re`.

    /Users/runner/work/neovim/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/shared.lua:796: attempt to index field 're' (a nil value)

to workaround this, try:

```suggestion
local _trim_pattern = vim.re and vim.re.compile('%s* {(%s* %S+)*}') or nil
```

then below,

    return _trim_pattern and _trim_pattern:match(s) or (s:match('^%s*(.*%S)') or '')

alternatively, could make the `vim.re` module available by updating `src/nvim/CMakeLists.txt` (I think?). @bfredl @zeertzjq any reason `vim.re` can't be available for `nvim -ll` ?

+local _trim_pattern = vim.re.compile('%s* {(%s* %S+)*}')

 function vim.trim(s)
   vim.validate('s', s, 'string')
-  return s:match('^%s*(.*%S)') or ''
+  return _trim_pattern:match(s)

comment_data.body: @justinmk Maybe then using lua loops with string.byte which is proposed by @glepnir in the issue is a better solution? And it is as fast if not faster than lpeg?

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -793,6 +793,7 @@ function vim._list_remove(t, first, last)
   end
 end
 
+local _trim_pattern = vim.re.compile('%s* {(%s* %S+)*}')

comment_data.body:
Yes. `{(%s* %S+)*}`.
`{}` - means return capture, not index
`()*` returns 0 or as many as possible matches. And if there is 0 it will return empty string, previsously trimming whitespaces with `^%s*`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -801,7 +802,7 @@ end
 ---@return string String with whitespace removed from its beginning and end
 function vim.trim(s)
   vim.validate('s', s, 'string')
-  return s:match('^%s*(.*%S)') or ''
+  return _trim_pattern:match(s)

comment_data.body:
The ["conditional gsub"](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34122#issuecomment-2901559179) solution is not a lot of code. It also outperforms lpeg approach in the other edge case of the very wide string that doesn't need trimming.

The downside of the `vim.re` approach is that it will always source `require('vim.re')` on startup, which has not quite negligible effect. On my machine a `nvim --clean -u init-vimre.lua` with 'init-vimre.lua' containing single line `local _trim_pattern = vim.re.compile('%s* {(%s* %S+)*}')` adds about 0.7ms to startup compared to overall about 10.3 ms of "Embedded" part of startup.

It passes tests.

comment_data.body: Can you add a comment here explaining why we don't use just `match`. This I'll prevent anyone changing this in the future.

-  return s:match('^%s*(.*%S)') or ''

comment_data.body:
Maybe also mention `gsub('%s+$', '')` case (as it is not intuitive)?

```suggestion
  -- `match('^%s*(.*%S)')` is slow for long whitespace strings
  -- `gsub('%s+$', '')` is slow for strings with many whitespace characters
  -- See PR #34122 for more details
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -801,7 +801,9 @@ end
 ---@return string String with whitespace removed from its beginning and end
 function vim.trim(s)
   vim.validate('s', s, 'string')
-  return s:match('^%s*(.*%S)') or ''
+  -- `s:match('^%s*(.*%S)')` is slow for long whitespace strings,
+  -- so we are forced to split it into to parts to prevent this

comment_regular_data.body:
@bfredl @zeertzjq 
Is using this version better, than dealing with `vim.re` in `shared.lua`?
```lua
function vim.trim(s)
  vim.validate('s', s, 'string')
  local byte, sub = string.byte, string.sub
  local len = #s

  if len == 0 then return '' end

  if byte(s, 1) > 32 and byte(s, len) > 32 then return s end

  local start = 1
  while start <= len and byte(s, start) <= 32 do
    start = start + 1
  end

  if start > len then return '' end

  local stop = len
  while stop >= start and byte(s, stop) <= 32 do
    stop = stop - 1
  end

  return sub(s, start, stop)
end
```
discussed on matrix, likely will enable `vim.re` for shared.lua.

I am late to the party, but the following approach is more performant than current one and compares okay to compiled pattern for bad case:

```lua
local trim4 = function(s)
  return (s:gsub('^%s+', ''):gsub('%s+$', ''))
end
```

Output of benchmarking from [this comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34097#issuecomment-2893936586):

```
Time: 220.193 ms -- current
Time: 0.013 ms   -- lpeg
Time: 0.006 ms   -- @glepnir's mega performant
Time: 0.024 ms   -- two gsub
----------------------
Time: 0.001 ms
Time: 0.001 ms
Time: 0.001 ms
Time: 0.001 ms
----------------------
Time: 0.050 ms
Time: 0.014 ms
Time: 0.006 ms
Time: 0.024 ms
----------------------
```

@echasnovski Benchmarks are incomplete. And your version degrades (not that much so) with long non-whitespace strings (I think I have tested something similar, and because I wasn't aware of `shared.lua` limitations I had come up with that solution). Try to replace spaces in str1 to any char). And current `string.match()` is good for long non-whitespace strings.

glepnir version behaves the best with any input. And it doesn't require changes to `shared.lua`. Maybe it is best solution?

I know it's not too frequent but the string.byte version doesn't trim double-width whitespace.


```lua

local function byte_trim(s)
  vim.validate('s', s, 'string')
  local byte, sub = string.byte, string.sub
  local len = #s

  if len == 0 then return '' end

  if byte(s, 1) > 32 and byte(s, len) > 32 then return s end

  local start = 1
  while start <= len and byte(s, start) <= 32 do
    start = start + 1
  end

  if start > len then return '' end

  local stop = len
  while stop >= start and byte(s, stop) <= 32 do
    stop = stop - 1
  end

  return sub(s, start, stop)
end

local double_width_string = '　　　　　　　'

local byte_trim_string = byte_trim(double_width_string) -- returns '　　　　　　　'
local current_trim = vim.trim(double_width_string) -- returns ''
```

@lucario387 good catch.
Seems like a blocker for `string.byte` version. Maybe it can be adjusted? Are there many "double" whitespaces chars?

There is also
```lua
local trim5 = function(s)
  return (s:gsub('^%s+', ''):match('.*%S') or '')
end
```
Which is good for any input. But i'm not sure how lua/luajit optimizes this. Is there two allocations? Can gc be a problem for long strings?

> Maybe it can be adjusted? Are there many "double" whitespaces chars?

I'm very much unsure since for double-width whitespace in Japanese code yields `string.len("　") = 3`, and the first byte is `227`. Not sure about Chinese and Korean variants (if they do exist as separate codes). But then that means monkey patching for specific case that could've been covered by the lpeg pattern or double gsub version

> @echasnovski Benchmarks are incomplete. And your version degrades (not that much so) with long non-whitespace strings (I think I have tested something similar, and because I wasn't aware of `shared.lua` limitations I had come up with that solution). Try to replace spaces in str1 to any char). And current `string.match()` is good for long non-whitespace strings.

Yes, indeed it does. This is easily fixable, though:

```lua
local trim4 = function(s)
  s = s:sub(1, 1):match('%s') and s:gsub('^%s+', '') or s
  s = s:sub(-1, -1):match('%s') and s:gsub('%s+$', '') or s
  return s
end
```

Benchmarks for previous cases are the same. Here are benchmarks for the string that contains the same number of `x` as the first "long" whitespace string:

```
Time: 0.003 ms -- current
Time: 0.015 ms -- lpeg
Time: 0.001 ms -- @glepnir's mega performant
Time: 0.001 ms -- two conditional gsub
```

**Edit**: seems to also be better than [this version](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34122#issuecomment-2901554643) on `str3` and "many x" strings. Usually having several non-anchored quantified patterns adds performance problems.

> And what if there are one space at each side? Still have the same issue of possible double allocations for long strings. Then gc could be a problem more than trim itself.

I don't think this degree of performance optimization is needed here. There is an example of extreme degradation with current approach (wide whitespace only string), the "conditional gsub" approach fixes it. While at the same time being more performant than lpeg one for the wide string without leading or trailing spaces.

If there is benchmarking approach for the problem you describe, then we can find a better solution.

> I don't think this degree of performance optimization is needed here. 

I do agree that this microseconds are pointless chase.

> @echasnovski I have updated benchmarks for all worst cases. Your implementation of gsub gsub degrade poorly for strings with big whitespace gaps in it.

Yeah, I can reproduce the same tendency of results. Nice find!

I also tested if this is indeed due to memory allocations for temporary string after `gsub()`, but it doesn't look like. The similar approach, but only with `:find()` shows similar performance.

The issue seems to be indeed the `'%s+$'` anchoring. Probably LuaJIT implementation has to do some backtracking which is costly in this case. Don't know.

Here is a bit more copy-paste-friendly version of the benchmarking code:

<details><summary>Code</summary>

```lua
-- Functions ------------------------------------------------------------------
local funcs = {}

function funcs.match_trim(str) return str:match('^%s*(.*%S)') or '' end

local trim_pattern = vim.re.compile('%s* {(%s* %S+)*}')
function funcs.lpeg_trim(s) return trim_pattern:match(s) end

function funcs.gsub_gsub_trim(s) return (s:gsub('^%s+', ''):gsub('%s+$', '')) end

function funcs.gsub_match_trim(s) return (s:gsub('^%s+', ''):match('.*%S') or '') end

function funcs.nitpicking_gsub_gsub(s)
  s = s:sub(1, 1):match('%s') and s:gsub('^%s+', '', 1) or s
  s = s:sub(-1, -1):match('%s') and s:gsub('%s+$', '', 1) or s
  return s
end

function funcs.find_sub(s)
  local _, from = s:find('^%s*')
  local to = s:find('%s*$')
  return s:sub(from + 1, to - 1)
end

local func_names = vim.tbl_keys(funcs)
table.sort(func_names)

-- Strings --------------------------------------------------------------------
local strings = {}

strings.short = ' \n \t hello \r \v'
strings.ten_thousand_white = string.rep(' ', 10000)
strings.ten_thousand_chars = string.rep('a', 10000)
strings.ten_thousand_gaps = ' a' .. string.rep(' ', 9998) .. 'a '
strings.ten_thousand_chars_with_spaces = ' ' .. string.rep('a', 10000) .. ' '

local string_names = vim.tbl_keys(strings)
table.sort(string_names)

-- Benchmark ------------------------------------------------------------------
local n = 10

local function benchmark(func, ...)
  func(...)
  local start = os.clock()
  for _ = 1, n do
    func(...)
  end
  local elapsed = (os.clock() - start) / n

  return string.format('%.3f ms', elapsed * 1000)
end

for _, f_name in ipairs(func_names) do
  local f = funcs[f_name]
  print(f_name .. ':')
  for _, s_name in ipairs(string_names) do
    print('  ' .. s_name .. ' - ' .. benchmark(f, strings[s_name]))
  end
  print(' ')
end
```

</details>

<details><summary>My output</summary>

```
find_sub:
  short - 0.001 ms
  ten_thousand_chars - 0.183 ms
  ten_thousand_chars_with_spaces - 0.196 ms
  ten_thousand_gaps - 274.004 ms
  ten_thousand_white - 0.058 ms

gsub_gsub_trim:
  short - 0.000 ms
  ten_thousand_chars - 0.076 ms
  ten_thousand_chars_with_spaces - 0.065 ms
  ten_thousand_gaps - 274.388 ms
  ten_thousand_white - 0.026 ms

gsub_match_trim:
  short - 0.000 ms
  ten_thousand_chars - 0.005 ms
  ten_thousand_chars_with_spaces - 0.003 ms
  ten_thousand_gaps - 0.003 ms
  ten_thousand_white - 0.026 ms

lpeg_trim:
  short - 0.000 ms
  ten_thousand_chars - 0.017 ms
  ten_thousand_chars_with_spaces - 0.017 ms
  ten_thousand_gaps - 0.014 ms
  ten_thousand_white - 0.014 ms

match_trim:
  short - 0.000 ms
  ten_thousand_chars - 0.003 ms
  ten_thousand_chars_with_spaces - 0.003 ms
  ten_thousand_gaps - 0.003 ms
  ten_thousand_white - 278.231 ms

nitpicking_gsub_gsub:
  short - 0.001 ms
  ten_thousand_chars - 0.000 ms
  ten_thousand_chars_with_spaces - 0.065 ms
  ten_thousand_gaps - 274.169 ms
  ten_thousand_white - 0.026 ms
```

</details>

@lucario387
I have done manual testing of `test/functional/lua/vim_spec.lua`. You were right `assert` in the tests always true, because it checks only if first arg is truthy ( not nil ).
But at the same time you have confused me - pattern `%s` doesn't respect "IDEOGRAPHIC SPACE" char either. And current `vim.trim` doesn't trim it. So using loops and string.byte is viable solution and behaves the same as trimming with lua patterns `%s` and `%S`.
Maybe in modern UTF-8 era it should detect such chars, but it is out of scope of this implementation.

> But at the same time you have confused me - pattern %s doesn't respect "IDEOGRAPHIC SPACE" char either


I found the same issue too. On my linux setup the double width whitespace was consumed while today I tested on windows and nothing was trimmed, leading to the assert check weirdness. Will test again on linux later today.

Very sorry for the wrong callout.🙇

> The issue seems to be indeed the `'%s+$'` anchoring. Probably LuaJIT implementation has to do some backtracking which is costly in this case. Don't know.

I was curious and did little digging. It is a known issue present both in LuaJIT and plain Lua: LuaJIT/LuaJIT#118. Probably won't be solved.

The `s:gsub('^%s+', ''):match('^.*%S') or ''` approach still seems to be the best here. Especially since it is documented to use 'Lua pattern "%s"' as the definition of whitespace, so taking "IDEOGRAPHIC SPACE" into account might be a bit extra here.

> The `s:gsub('^%s+', ''):match('^.*%S') or ''` approach still seems to be the best here.

a 2-line change is welcome. a 30-line change is not, especially when the difference is not significant.

> Is there any reason for this? There are much larger functions in `shared.lua`

if those functions could be achieved with 80% less code at a 5% perf cost, then they wouldn't be like that.

@echasnovski @justinmk my apology, `%s` is only 9,10,11,12,13 and 32 bytes. So vim.trim() shouldn't trim any other char below 32 byte and glipnir implementation was wrong from the start.
Reverting to `gsub`+`match`.
I think the benchmarking code is probably worth including in `benchmark/`. And also a comment explaining why `vim.trim` is implemented the way it is.
yes at the moment it's just for local use. We don't run any of it in CI.

title: perf(runtime): vim.trim for long only whitespace strings
